62666e73-36bb-498c-bcbb-59d151bc4fc8.name: Create a test that ensures various widths of browsers have no scrollbars
62666e73-36bb-498c-bcbb-59d151bc4fc8.desc:
If there is any horizontal overflow, a horizontal scrollbar will appear. If this happens, by even a single pixel, scrolling on mobile becomes very janky. Usually, horizontal overflow is introduced unintentionally by adding some HTML element. We would like to have a test that simply loads various pages and detects the presence of a horizontal scrollbar.

It is possible to check whether or not the horizontal scrollbar exists by comparing the width of the screen to the width of the document's body. If the screen width is smaller than the document, then there will be a horizontal scrollbar.

You can check the screen width using this Javascript:

```javascript
document.body.clientWidth
```

And you can check the document's width using this Javascript:

```javascript
document.body.scrollWidth
```

Basically, the test needs to fail if `scrollWidth > clientWidth`. In playwright, this code needs to be evaluated in the context of the browser. This can be achieved using `page.evaluate` like this:

```javascript
page.evaluate(() => {
  return document.body.clientWidth;
});
```

To complete this task, do the following:

1. Write a function `hasHorizontalScrollbar()` that returns true if we detect that `document.body.scrollWidth > document.body.clientWidth`.

2. Use this function to write tests that check for a horizontal scrollbar on the planning page, the inbox page, and the projects page.

To test that the function is working, introduce a horizontal scrollbar. Kyle and I first ran in to this problem when we added the crown badge. We fixed it in this PR: https://github.com/kosolabs/koso/pull/1103

You can verify that the test fails by removing the `overflow-hidden` from the navbar, which will reintroduce the horizontal scrollbar bug.

b6602bee-aedd-4eaf-98ac-77da6283b821.name: Linking a GitHub PR to a task causes the task's estimate to be overridden by the managed task's non-existent estimate
b6602bee-aedd-4eaf-98ac-77da6283b821.desc:
Repro:

- Estimate a task (say, koso-100)
- Write a PR, and link the task in the PR (e.g., set the PR title to "koso-100: Fix the task")

After linking the PR, koso-100 will become a rollup task and as a result will ignore its existing estimate. The linked PR is a managed task, so it won't let you estimate it. We end up in a situation where the task and the PR are no longer estimateable.

We need to think of a way to handle this situation gracefully.

IZ4a0xR9TcaFM4rvtFPahg.desc:
Koso is a collaborative project planning application engineered for efficiency and intelligent automation. Its core purpose is to minimize planning overhead, allowing teams to focus on execution. Koso achieves this through real-time collaborative task management, a flexible graph-based task model, and deep integrations with external services and AI agents.

## 2. System Architecture

Koso operates as a full-stack web application, clearly segmenting its backend and frontend services.

**Backend Services:**
The backend is meticulously crafted in **Rust**, leveraging the **Axum** web framework. It serves as the central intelligence, managing all business logic, data persistence, and real-time communication.

*   **API Layer**: Exposes comprehensive RESTful endpoints for user authentication, project administration, profile configuration, and seamless integration with external services.
*   **Real-time Collaboration**: Employs **WebSockets** and **Yjs** (a powerful CRDT library) to ensure real-time synchronization of project data across all connected clients, guaranteeing data consistency and conflict resolution.
*   **Database Interaction**: Utilizes **SQLx** for efficient asynchronous PostgreSQL database access, handling schema migrations and all data manipulation operations.
*   **Integrations Hub**: Functions as a central conduit for connecting with external services such as GitHub, Stripe, Discord, Slack, and Telegram. It processes incoming webhooks and orchestrates outgoing API calls.
*   **AI Integration**: Provides dedicated endpoints for interacting with AI agents via the **Model Context Protocol (MCP)** and supports direct Anthropic API streaming for generative AI features.
*   **Monitoring**: Exposes **Prometheus** compatible metrics for comprehensive observability and includes a basic `/healthz` endpoint for liveness checks.

**Frontend Services:**
The frontend is a dynamic Single-Page Application (SPA) developed with **SvelteKit** and **TypeScript**, delivering a responsive and interactive user experience.

*   **User Interface**: Renders intuitive interactive task lists, project dashboards, and user profiles, built upon a custom component library styled with **Tailwind CSS**.
*   **Real-time UI**: Integrates directly with Yjs to visually represent real-time updates and user presence (awareness) for collaborative editing sessions.
*   **API Consumption**: Communicates with the backend exclusively via RESTful API calls for data operations and WebSockets for real-time data synchronization.
*   **Client-side Routing**: Manages efficient navigation within the application, ensuring a fluid user experience.
*   **State Management**: Leverages Svelte's inherent reactivity model and `localStorage` for persistent client-side state.

**Deployment and Infrastructure:**
The entire application is meticulously **Dockerized**, ensuring consistent environments across development, testing, and production.

*   **CI/CD**: **GitHub Actions** automate the entire software delivery lifecycle, encompassing build, test, and deployment processes for both backend and frontend components.
*   **Dependency Management**: **Dependabot** and **Renovate** are configured to automatically identify and propose updates for all third-party dependencies, maintaining a secure and up-to-date codebase.
*   **Database**: **PostgreSQL** serves as the robust relational database, providing transactional integrity and supporting efficient data storage.
*   **Reverse Proxy**: **Caddy** acts as the production reverse proxy, handling SSL termination, request routing to the backend, and serving static frontend assets.
*   **Health Check**: A dedicated `healthz` service periodically monitors the main application's health, alerting on status changes.

The system's design emphasizes horizontal scalability, with most backend components designed to be stateless (excluding the PostgreSQL connection pool and transient in-memory Yjs document states, which are short-lived per-project connections).

## 3. Core Components

### 3.1. Backend Components (`backend/src`)

*   **`api.rs`**: This foundational module defines the overarching API router for the Koso application. It incorporates shared middleware for authentication, granular authorization checks (e.g., premium status validation, project access control), and a standardized `ErrorResponse` structure for consistent API error handling. Utility functions like `unauthenticated_error` and `bad_request_error` ensure uniform error messaging and comprehensive logging.
*   **`server.rs`**: Orchestrates the main Axum HTTP server. It is responsible for initializing the PostgreSQL connection pool, applying global middleware (including request ID injection, detailed request tracing, metrics emission, and debug logging), and efficiently serving static frontend assets. It integrates `listenfd` for hot-reloading in development environments and implements graceful shutdown mechanisms via `CancellationToken`.
*   **`settings.rs` & `secrets.rs`**: These modules provide a robust system for managing application configuration and sensitive data. `settings.rs` loads environment-specific configurations (development or production) from structured JSON files and environment variables. `secrets.rs` offers a secure method to read sensitive data (e.g., API keys, tokens) from a designated `.secrets` directory outside the codebase, preventing their accidental inclusion in version control.
*   **`healthz.rs`**: Defines a simple `/healthz` endpoint, primarily used by external monitoring systems and the dedicated `healthz` cronjob to ascertain the backend service's operational status.
*   **`metrics_server.rs`**: Sets up a dedicated HTTP server for exposing Prometheus-compatible metrics. This includes standard HTTP request duration and total request counts, alongside custom application-specific metrics, enabling integration with monitoring dashboards like Grafana.
*   **`collab/` (Collaboration Logic)**: This directory encapsulates the real-time collaboration engine, powered by Yjs, which is central to Koso's interactive experience.
    *   **`projects_state.rs`**: Manages the lifecycle of `YDocProxy` instances for each active project. It handles WebSocket client connections, maintains user awareness states, and coordinates the loading and saving of collaborative documents. Mechanisms are in place to limit concurrent clients per project to prevent server overload and to gracefully clean up inactive project states.
    *   **`client_messages.rs`**: Processes binary messages received from WebSocket clients. It is responsible for decoding standard Yjs synchronization messages (`SYNC_REQUEST`, `SYNC_RESPONSE`, `SYNC_UPDATE`) and Koso-specific awareness updates.
    *   **`doc_updates.rs`**: Contains observers that react to changes within `YDocProxy` instances. It ensures that document updates are persisted reliably to the `yupdates` table in the database and efficiently broadcast to all other connected clients for the respective project. It also includes a `GraphObserver` to automatically detect and resolve task number conflicts.
    *   **`storage.rs`**: Dedicated to handling the persistence of Yjs document updates to the PostgreSQL `yupdates` table. It supports loading historical updates to reconstruct a document's state and implements a compaction mechanism to merge multiple small updates into larger ones, optimizing storage and retrieval.
    *   **`awareness.rs`**: Defines the data structures and logic for managing and transmitting real-time user presence information (e.g., currently selected tasks, active cursor positions) among collaborators within a project.
    *   **`msg_sync.rs`**: Contains constants and utility functions for encoding and decoding Yjs and Koso-specific WebSocket messages, strictly adhering to the Yjs protocol for interoperability.
    *   **`txn_origin.rs`**: Provides utilities for attaching rich origin metadata (identifying the user, source, and unique transaction ID) to Yjs transactions, which is crucial for auditing changes and triggering subsequent event processing.
    *   **`notifications.rs`**: Observes deep changes in the Yjs document graph (e.g., task assignment changes, status updates, child task removals) and dispatches `KosoEvent`s. These events then trigger notifications via various configured notification channels.
*   **`yproxy.rs`**: Provides a Rust-idiomatic interface (`YDocProxy`, `YTaskProxy`) for interacting with Yjs's underlying `YDoc` and `YMap` collaborative structures. This module simplifies task manipulation and graph traversal within the Rust application, defining the precise mapping between Koso's internal `Task` struct and Yjs primitives.
*   **`plugins/`**: Defines an extensible and modular architecture for integrating with various third-party services.
    *   **`github/`**: Implements the comprehensive GitHub integration.
        *   **`app.rs`**: Provides an `AppGithub` client for authenticating as a GitHub App installation and fetching relevant data such as repositories and pull requests.
        *   **`connect.rs`**: Handles the GitHub OAuth flow for connecting both user accounts and project installations, securely storing their configurations in the `plugin_configs` table.
        *   **`poller.rs`**: Periodically polls connected GitHub installations for pull request updates, syncing them as tasks into Koso projects. It manages both initial task creation and subsequent updates.
        *   **`webhook.rs`**: Processes incoming GitHub webhook events (e.g., pull request opened, closed, edited), applying real-time updates to corresponding Koso tasks. It includes robust signature validation for security.
    *   **`config.rs`**: Manages the secure storage and retrieval of `PluginConfig`s from the database, allowing plugins to persist their specific settings uniquely per project and external identifier.
*   **`notifiers/`**: Implements Koso's multi-channel notification system, enabling communication with various messaging platforms.
    *   **`discord.rs`**, **`slack.rs`**, **`telegram.rs`**: Each module provides dedicated clients and webhook handlers for integrating with Discord, Slack, and Telegram, respectively. They support platform-specific OAuth authorization flows and are responsible for sending messages based on Koso events.
*   **`billing/`**: Manages all subscription and billing logic, primarily integrating with Stripe.
    *   **`stripe.rs`**: Contains the Stripe API client, facilitating the creation of checkout sessions and comprehensive management of user subscriptions.
    *   **`webhook.rs`**: Processes incoming Stripe webhook events (e.g., `checkout.session.completed`, `invoice.paid`, `customer.subscription.*`), dynamically updating user premium status and subscription details within the Koso database. It includes stringent signature validation.
*   **`mcp.rs`**: Implements a server for the **Model Context Protocol (MCP)**, enabling AI agents (such as Claude Code or VS Code Copilot) to programmatically interact with Koso projects. It exposes tools like `create_task` and `list_projects`, providing AI agents with structured access to Koso's data model.
*   **`dev.rs`**: Contains development-specific API endpoints. These endpoints, such as `cleanup_test_data` (for removing old test user data) and `invite_test_user` (for granting premium access to test users), are strictly isolated to development environments.

### 3.2. Frontend Components (`frontend/src`)

*   **`app.css`**: Defines global styles for the application using Tailwind CSS. This includes custom CSS variables for the Material 3 color palette, supporting both light and dark modes, and foundational styling for base HTML elements.
*   **`lib/`**: Contains core application logic, reusable utilities, and major UI components.
    *   **`auth.svelte`**: Manages the user authentication state. It handles Google OAuth login flows and provides a global authentication context accessible throughout the application.
    *   **`api.ts`**: Provides utility functions for making authenticated HTTP requests to the backend API. It standardizes response parsing and error handling across the frontend.
    *   **`dag-table/`**: This is the core UI module for project planning and inbox management, implementing the directed acyclic graph (DAG) structure of tasks.
        *   **`koso.svelte`**: Encapsulates the main Yjs document (`Y.Doc`) for a specific project. It handles its initialization, maintains real-time synchronization with the backend via WebSockets, and exposes methods for creating, updating, and deleting tasks. It also integrates Yjs's built-in undo/redo history.
        *   **`planning-context.svelte`**: Manages the intricate UI state for the project planning table. This includes tracking selected nodes, expanded/collapsed sections of the graph, and handling drag-and-drop interactions for task reordering and linking.
        *   **`inbox-context.svelte`**: Manages the UI state and logic for the "Zero Inbox" view. It filters tasks based on user assignments and actionability criteria, presenting a prioritized list of tasks requiring attention.
        *   **`dag-row.svelte`**, **`task-row.svelte`**: Svelte components responsible for rendering individual task rows within the planning and inbox tables, respectively. They handle the display of task properties, enable inline editing, and manage interactive elements.
        *   **`link-node-panel.svelte`**, **`link-task-panel.svelte`**: Provide the user interface for linking or blocking tasks on other tasks within the project graph. These components include search and auto-completion functionalities for efficient task discovery.
        *   **`awareness.svelte`**: Visualizes real-time user presence and selection within the collaborative document, displaying who is currently interacting with specific tasks.
        *   **`detail-panel.svelte`**: A dynamic panel for viewing and editing task descriptions. It integrates a Markdown editor (CodeMirror) and a viewer for rich text content.
    *   **`components/ui/`**: A collection of reusable, generic UI components such as buttons, inputs, menus, and various visual indicators. These are built with Svelte and styled using Tailwind CSS.
    *   **`kosui/`**: Koso's internal UI framework (likely a custom library or extension of a base component library), providing a consistent design system with foundational components like `Box`, `Button`, `Input`, `Dialog`, `Modal`, `Popover`, and `Tooltip`. It defines consistent variants, colors, and shapes.
    *   **`navigation-action.ts`**, **`shortcuts.ts`**: Define application-wide keyboard shortcuts and navigation actions. These are integrated into a central command palette and are accessible throughout the user interface for enhanced productivity.
    *   **`github.ts`**: Frontend helper functions for initiating GitHub OAuth flows and managing connections between Koso projects/users and GitHub installations.
    *   **`projects.ts`**, **`users.ts`**: Frontend API clients responsible for interacting with the backend's project and user management endpoints, abstracting API calls.
    *   **`yproxy.ts`**: TypeScript definitions for the Yjs document structure. These mirror the Rust `yproxy` types, ensuring strong type safety and consistent data representation across both the frontend and backend.
    *   **`stores.svelte`**: Svelte utility functions for integrating with `localStorage` to manage persistent client-side state, such as user preferences.
    *   **`anthropic-stream.svelte`**: Handles streaming responses from the Anthropic API for Large Language Model (LLM) features, such as task summarization and breakdown, by parsing server-sent events (SSE).

## 4. Data Model

The core data model of Koso revolves around projects, users, and tasks, with persistence handled by PostgreSQL and real-time synchronization managed by Yjs.

**PostgreSQL Tables:**

*   **`projects`**: Stores high-level project metadata.
    *   `project_id` (VARCHAR(36), PK): Unique identifier for each project.
    *   `name` (VARCHAR(36)): The display name of the project.
    *   `deleted_on` (TIMESTAMPTZ, NULLABLE): A timestamp indicating when a project was soft-deleted, enabling recovery and historical tracking.
    *   `llm_context` (TEXT, NULLABLE): Stores context specific to LLM interactions for the project.
*   **`users`**: Stores user profiles and authentication-related information.
    *   `email` (VARCHAR(320), PK): The user's unique email address, serving as the primary identifier.
    *   `name` (VARCHAR(255)): The user's display name.
    *   `picture` (VARCHAR(2048)): URL to the user's profile picture.
    *   `creation_time` (TIMESTAMPTZ): Timestamp indicating when the user account was created.
    *   `login_time` (TIMESTAMPTZ, NULLABLE): Timestamp of the user's last login.
    *   `github_user_id` (TEXT, NULLABLE): The user's GitHub user ID, populated if their GitHub account is connected.
    *   `subscription_end_time` (TIMESTAMPTZ, NULLABLE): Indicates premium status; a non-null and future timestamp implies an active premium subscription.
*   **`project_permissions`**: Defines access control, linking users to the projects they can access.
    *   `project_id` (VARCHAR(36), PK): Foreign key referencing the `projects` table.
    *   `email` (VARCHAR(320), PK): Foreign key referencing the `users` table.
*   **`yupdates`**: Stores the granular, sequential updates to Yjs documents, enabling real-time collaboration and historical reconstruction.
    *   `project_id` (VARCHAR(36), PK): Foreign key referencing the `projects` table.
    *   `seq` (SERIAL, PK): A sequence number for updates within a project, ensuring strict ordering of changes.
    *   `update_v2` (BYTEA): The binary representation of the Yjs update, using the efficient v2 encoding.
*   **`plugin_configs`**: Stores configurations for various external service plugins, scoped per project and external integration.
    *   `project_id` (VARCHAR(36), PK): Foreign key referencing the `projects` table.
    *   `plugin_id` (VARCHAR(64), PK): An identifier for the specific plugin (e.g., "github").
    *   `external_id` (VARCHAR(64), PK): An external identifier relevant to the plugin (e.g., a GitHub installation ID).
    *   `settings` (JSONB): A JSONB column storing plugin-specific configuration settings (e.g., `GithubSettings`).
*   **`user_notification_configs`**: Stores user-specific preferences and authorization details for notification channels.
    *   `email` (VARCHAR(320), PK): Foreign key referencing the `users` table.
    *   `notifier` (VARCHAR(64), PK): Identifier for the notification channel (e.g., "discord", "slack", "telegram").
    *   `enabled` (BOOLEAN): A flag indicating whether the notification channel is active for the user.
    *   `settings` (JSONB): A JSONB column containing notifier-specific settings (e.g., Discord channel ID).
*   **`subscriptions`**: Stores detailed information about user subscriptions for premium features.
    *   `email` (VARCHAR(320), PK): The email of the primary owner of the subscription.
    *   `stripe_customer_id` (TEXT): The corresponding customer ID from Stripe.
    *   `end_time` (TIMESTAMPTZ): The subscription end time, determining active premium status.
    *   `seats` (INTEGER): The number of allowed members under this subscription.
    *   `member_emails` (VARCHAR(320)[]): An array of email addresses for users covered by the subscription.
*   **`oauth_clients`**: Stores metadata for OAuth 2.0 clients that interact with the MCP server.
    *   `client_id` (VARCHAR(64), PK): Unique identifier for the OAuth client.
    *   `creation_time` (TIMESTAMPTZ): Timestamp indicating when the OAuth client was registered.
    *   `client_metadata` (JSONB): A JSONB column storing detailed metadata about the client, including its name, redirect URIs, and supported grant types.

**Yjs Document Structure (`YDocProxy` & `YTaskProxy`):**
The core `Task` entity is collaboratively edited using Yjs, providing real-time updates and conflict resolution.

*   **`YDoc`**: The root collaborative document for each Koso project. It contains a main `YMap` named "graph".
*   **`graph` (YMap)**: This central YMap stores all tasks within a project. Keys are `task_id`s (UUIDs encoded as base64 URL-safe strings), and values are nested `YMap`s representing individual tasks.
*   **`Task` (YMap)**: Each YMap within the "graph" represents a single task in the collaborative project plan. It includes the following fields:
    *   `id` (String): The unique identifier for the task (identical to its key in the "graph" YMap).
    *   `num` (String): The display number of the task (e.g., "1", "1.1", "2.3.4").
    *   `name` (String): The title or short description of the task.
    *   `desc` (YText, Optional): A collaborative rich text field for detailed task descriptions.
    *   `children` (YArray): An array of `task_id`s, representing direct subtasks, forming the hierarchical structure of the project plan.
    *   `assignee` (String, Optional): The email of the user currently assigned to the task.
    *   `reporter` (String, Optional): The email of the user who created or reported the task.
    *   `status` (String, Optional): The current status of the task (e.g., "Not Started", "In Progress", "Done", "Blocked", "Ready").
    *   `status_time` (i64, Optional): Unix timestamp of the last status change.
    *   `url` (String, Optional): An external URL related to the task (e.g., a GitHub Pull Request link).
    *   `kind` (String, Optional): The type of task (e.g., "Task", "Rollup", "Iteration", "github_pr"), allowing for specialized behaviors.
    *   `estimate` (i64, Optional): Estimated effort for the task, typically expressed in points.
    *   `deadline` (i64, Optional): Unix timestamp indicating the task's deadline, especially relevant for "Iteration" kind tasks.
    *   `archived` (Boolean, Optional): A flag indicating if the task is archived (hidden from primary views but not deleted).

## 5. API Endpoints

The backend exposes a well-defined set of RESTful and WebSocket API endpoints, structured for clear functionality.

**Authentication & Authorization:**

*   `POST /api/auth/login`: Authenticates a user based on a Google ID token, creating or updating their profile in the database.
*   `middleware::from_fn(google::authenticate)`: A core middleware responsible for applying JWT validation (specifically, Google ID tokens) and injecting the authenticated user's context into request handlers for protected routes.
*   `verify_premium`, `verify_project_access`: Internal functions utilized by handlers for granular authorization checks, enforcing premium feature access and project-specific permissions.

**Projects:**

*   `GET /api/projects`: Retrieves a list of all projects accessible by the authenticated user.
*   `POST /api/projects`: Creates a new Koso project. It optionally supports importing tasks from a JSON export file, facilitating project bootstrapping.
*   `GET /api/projects/{project_id}`: Fetches detailed information for a specific project identified by its `project_id`.
*   `PATCH /api/projects/{project_id}`: Updates mutable metadata for an existing project (e.g., changing its `name`).
*   `DELETE /api/projects/{project_id}`: Initiates a soft-delete operation for a project, marking it as deleted but retaining data for a recovery period.
*   `GET /api/projects/{project_id}/users`: Lists all users who currently have access to the specified project.
*   `PATCH /api/projects/{project_id}/users`: Modifies user permissions for a project, allowing for the addition or removal of collaborators (a premium feature).
*   `GET /api/projects/{project_id}/updates`: Retrieves raw Yjs updates for a project, primarily intended for debugging or diagnostic purposes.
*   `GET /api/projects/{project_id}/export`: Exports the entire project data (including all tasks and their relationships) as a JSON graph.

**Users & Profile:**

*   `GET /api/profile`: Retrieves the authenticated user's complete profile, including their notification configurations, plugin connections, and current subscription details.
*   `GET /api/users`: Lists all premium users registered within Koso (requires premium status for the requesting user).
*   `GET /api/users/{email}`: Fetches detailed information for a specific user, accessible only by the authenticated user themselves.

**Real-time Collaboration:**

*   `GET /api/ws/projects/{project_id}`: The WebSocket endpoint for real-time collaborative editing of a project's Yjs document. It fully supports the Yjs synchronization and awareness protocols.

**AI Integration (Anthropic):**

*   `GET /api/anthropic/summarize`: Leverages a Large Language Model (LLM) to generate a concise summary of a given task and all its hierarchical children.
*   `GET /api/anthropic/breakdown`: Utilizes an LLM to break down a high-level task into a set of actionable subtasks.

**Model Context Protocol (MCP):**

*   `GET /api/mcp/sse`: A Server-Sent Events (SSE) endpoint serving as Koso's MCP server. It enables external AI agents and development tools (like VS Code Copilot, Claude Code) to discover available tools (`create_task`, `list_projects`) and interact with Koso's data programmatically.

**Notifications:**

*   `POST /api/notifiers`: Sends a test notification to all configured channels for the authenticated user.
*   `POST /api/notifiers/discord`, `DELETE /api/notifiers/discord`: Endpoints for authorizing and deauthorizing Koso's ability to send Discord notifications for a user.
*   `POST /api/notifiers/discord/interaction`: The webhook endpoint for Discord, used to process incoming interactions (e.g., the `/token` command).
*   Similar endpoints exist for `slack` and `telegram`, providing analogous authorization and webhook handling functionalities.

**Billing (Stripe):**

*   `POST /api/billing/stripe/create-checkout-session`: Initiates a Stripe Checkout session, guiding users through the process of subscribing to Koso's premium features.
*   `POST /api/billing/stripe/create-portal-session`: Creates a Stripe Customer Portal session, allowing users to manage their existing subscriptions (e.g., updating payment methods, changing plans).
*   `PUT /api/billing/subscriptions`: Updates subscription details, such as managing member emails under a team subscription (requires subscription ownership).
*   `POST /api/billing/stripe/webhook`: The Stripe webhook endpoint responsible for processing all subscription-related events (e.g., successful payments, status changes) and updating the Koso database accordingly.

**Development-only:**

*   `POST /api/dev/cleanup_test_data`: Deletes old test user data and any associated projects or Yjs updates, maintaining a clean test environment.
*   `POST /api/dev/invite_test_user`: Grants premium access to a specified test user for testing premium features.

**Plugins (GitHub):**

*   `POST /plugins/github/connect`: Connects a Koso project to a specific GitHub App installation.
*   `GET /plugins/github/init`: Provides essential GitHub App details (client ID, app name) to the frontend for initiating the OAuth flow.
*   `POST /plugins/github/userConnections`, `DELETE /plugins/github/userConnections`: Endpoints for connecting and disconnecting a Koso user's profile to their GitHub user ID.
*   `POST /plugins/github/app/webhook`: The GitHub webhook endpoint, configured to receive pull request events and other relevant notifications.
*   `POST /plugins/github/poll`: Manually triggers a GitHub polling cycle, primarily used in development for immediate synchronization.

## 6. Collaboration and Real-time Features

Koso's real-time collaboration is a cornerstone of its design, powered by Yjs and WebSockets, ensuring a seamless and consistent experience for multiple users working concurrently.

**Yjs Integration:**

*   **Conflict-Free Replicated Data Types (CRDTs)**: Yjs employs CRDTs, guaranteeing that concurrent edits from multiple users can be merged automatically and deterministically without conflicts. This inherently preserves data integrity and ensures that all clients eventually converge to the same state.
*   **`YDocProxy`**: Each Koso project maintains a single authoritative `YDoc` instance on the backend, exposed through `YDocProxy`. This `YDoc` acts as the central source of truth for the entire project graph, storing tasks, their relationships, and all properties as interconnected Yjs `YMap`s and `YArray`s.
*   **`YText` for Descriptions**: Task descriptions are stored specifically as `YText` fields within the `YMap`s representing tasks. This enables rich, character-by-character collaborative text editing, akin to Google Docs.
*   **Document Synchronization**: The synchronization process between clients and the server follows a precise protocol:
    *   When a client establishes a WebSocket connection, it sends a `SYNC_REQUEST` message containing its current `StateVector`. The `StateVector` efficiently summarizes the client's knowledge of the document's history.
    *   The server responds with a `SYNC_RESPONSE` message. This response contains all `Update`s necessary to bring the client's `YDoc` completely up-to-date with the server's authoritative state.
    *   As users make changes on the frontend, the client-side Yjs library generates `Update`s locally. These compact binary updates are then sent to the server as `SYNC_UPDATE` messages.
    *   The server applies these incoming `Update`s to its authoritative `YDoc` and then immediately broadcasts them to all other connected clients for that specific project. This ensures near real-time propagation of changes.
    *   All applied updates are diligently persisted to the PostgreSQL `yupdates` table. This persistence guarantees data durability and allows the entire project state to be reconstructed even after server restarts or in cases of data loss.

**Awareness System:**

*   **User Presence**: Beyond just collaborative editing, Koso implements an "awareness" feature. This allows users to actively see who else is currently viewing, selecting, or interacting with specific tasks within the collaborative document.
*   **`Awareness` (Yjs concept)**: The frontend sends lightweight `AwarenessUpdate` messages (containing a client ID, sequence number, and details of selected tasks) to the backend via WebSockets.
*   **Broadcast**: The backend aggregates these individual `AwarenessUpdate`s and periodically broadcasts the consolidated "awareness state" to all connected clients for the project. This enables the frontend UI to display real-time indicators like colored cursors, highlights, or user avatars next to tasks.

**Undo/Redo:**

*   Yjs inherently provides robust undo/redo functionality. It tracks all changes to the collaborative document as a series of atomic `Update`s, which can be reversed or re-applied.
*   The frontend client leverages Yjs's undo/redo stack to allow users to intuitively reverse or re-apply their local changes, maintaining consistency with the overall collaborative state.

## 7. Integrations

Koso integrates with several external services to automate workflows, enhance communication, and provide a more comprehensive planning experience.

*   **GitHub Integration (`plugins/github`)**:
    *   **Task Synchronization**: Pull Requests (PRs) from connected GitHub repositories can be automatically synchronized as tasks within Koso projects. This creates a bridge between development activities and project planning.
    *   **Status Updates**: Changes in GitHub PR status (e.g., `opened`, `closed`, `edited`) automatically update the corresponding Koso task status (e.g., "In Progress" to "Done"), ensuring the project plan reflects the latest development progress.
    *   **Linking**: GitHub PRs and issues can reference Koso tasks using a special syntax (e.g., `koso#123`). This automatically creates links within the Koso graph, providing traceability between code and plan.
    *   **Connection Flow**: Users connect Koso projects to GitHub installations via a secure OAuth flow, granting Koso the necessary permissions. Individual user GitHub accounts can also be linked to their Koso profiles for accurate assignee resolution in synchronized tasks.
    *   **Webhooks**: Real-time updates from GitHub are primarily driven by incoming webhooks, ensuring prompt synchronization and responsiveness to events like PR creation or merges.
    *   **Polling**: A background poller acts as a robust fallback mechanism for synchronization. It periodically fetches PR data, ensuring eventual consistency even if webhooks are missed or delayed.
*   **Stripe Integration (`api/billing`)**:
    *   **Subscription Management**: Handles the entire lifecycle of premium user subscriptions, from initial purchase to renewals and cancellations.
    *   **Checkout Flow**: Integrates with Stripe Checkout, providing a secure and streamlined process for new users to subscribe to Koso's premium features.
    *   **Customer Portal**: Offers a seamless way for existing users to manage their subscriptions (e.g., changing plans, updating payment methods) through Stripe's hosted customer portal, reducing administrative overhead.
    *   **Webhooks**: Listens for critical Stripe webhook events (e.g., `checkout.session.completed`, `invoice.paid`, `customer.subscription.created/updated/deleted`) to automatically update user `subscription_end_time` and `seats` in Koso's database, thereby granting or revoking premium features in real-time.
*   **AI (Anthropic/Gemini) Integration (`api/anthropic`, `api/gemini`)**:
    *   **Task Summarization**: Leverages large language models (LLMs) to generate concise, actionable summaries of tasks and their hierarchical children, significantly aiding in quick understanding of project iterations.
    *   **Task Breakdown**: Utilizes LLMs to break down high-level, complex tasks into more granular, actionable subtasks, assisting in detailed planning and decomposition.
    *   **Codebase Context Generation**: Employs LLMs (specifically Gemini) to generate design documentation based on an entire codebase by fetching and processing relevant source files from a GitHub repository.
    *   **Streaming**: Responses from the LLM are streamed to the frontend, providing a responsive and interactive user experience as content is generated incrementally.
*   **Notifier Integrations (`notifiers/`)**:
    *   **Discord, Slack, Telegram**: Users can authorize Koso to send notifications directly to their preferred messaging platforms.
    *   **Task Assignment Notifications**: When a task is assigned to a user, Koso automatically sends a notification to their configured channels, ensuring timely awareness.
    *   **Task Unblocking Notifications**: When a task (previously marked "Blocked") becomes actionable (i.e., all its dependencies are marked "Done"), the assigned user receives an automatic notification, prompting them to begin work.
    *   **OAuth/Webhook Flows**: Integrations involve platform-specific OAuth flows for secure authorization and webhook endpoints for receiving commands (e.g., Telegram's `/token` command).
*   **Model Context Protocol (MCP) (`mcp.rs`)**:
    *   **AI Agent Interoperability**: Koso exposes an MCP server, enabling external AI agents and development tools (like VS Code Copilot, Claude Code) to discover Koso's capabilities (e.g., `create_task`, `list_projects`) and interact with project data. This facilitates more sophisticated AI-driven workflows and automations within Koso.

## 8. Deployment and Operations

Koso is designed for robust deployment and operational efficiency, leveraging modern cloud-native practices.

*   **Dockerization**: Both the `backend` and `healthz` services are Dockerized. This provides isolated, consistent, and reproducible runtime environments. Multi-stage Docker builds are employed to optimize image size and accelerate build times.
*   **CI/CD Pipeline (GitHub Actions)**:
    *   **`ci.yml`**: This workflow executes a comprehensive suite of tests, including Rust `cargo test`, `clippy` (linting), and `fmt` (code formatting) for the backend, and Node.js `npm` tests and `playwright` end-to-end tests for the frontend. It also builds Docker images for both production (`kosolabs/koso`) and development (`kosolabs/koso/dev`) and pushes them to GitHub Container Registry (GHCR). Docker build cache is actively managed for faster iterative builds.
    *   **`deploy.yml`**: Triggered automatically on pushes to the `main` branch, this workflow orchestrates the entire deployment process. It retrieves the latest production image digest from the `ci.yml` output, then uses `appleboy/ssh-action` to securely execute the `deploy.sh` script on the production server.
*   **Deployment Script (`deploy.sh`)**:
    *   This script is executed directly on the target server (e.g., `koso.app`) via SSH.
    *   It performs a Git checkout to the specific `GITHUB_SHA`, ensuring the deployed code matches the committed version.
    *   It cleans up old Docker images and containers to reclaim disk space.
    *   It pulls the new Docker image (`ghcr.io/kosolabs/koso@$KOSO_IMAGE_DIGEST`).
    *   Crucially, it runs database migrations using the new Docker image (`./sqlx migrate run`) before starting the application, ensuring schema compatibility.
    *   It sets up PostgreSQL automated backups by copying `psql_backup.sh` and its cronjob configuration.
    *   It updates the `systemd` service unit file (`backend/koso.service`) with the new image digest and restarts the Koso service.
    *   A critical feature is its integrated rollback mechanism (`trap _on_fail ZERR`). If any step of the current deployment fails (including a post-deployment health check), it attempts to revert to the previously deployed, known-good version.
    *   It performs a final health check (`curl --fail http://localhost:3000/healthz`) to confirm successful deployment before marking it complete and updating the rollback state.
*   **PostgreSQL Backups (`backend/psql_backups/psql_backup.sh`)**:
    *   A daily cron job, configured by `deploy.sh`, automatically exports PostgreSQL database backups to a Google Cloud Storage bucket (`koso-psql-backups`).
    *   Backups are compressed using `gzip` (`.sql.gz`). The bucket is configured with soft deletion and object versioning, providing robust data retention and simplified recovery.
    *   Detailed instructions for manual restoration from GCP are provided within the `README.md`.
*   **Observability**:
    *   **Tracing**: The `tracing` and `tracing-subscriber` crates provide structured logging capabilities with `env_filter` support for dynamic log level configuration, enabling fine-grained debugging and monitoring.
    *   **Metrics**: The `metrics_exporter_prometheus` crate exposes application metrics (e.g., HTTP request counts and durations) on a dedicated port (`:3001`), allowing for seamless integration with external monitoring systems like Grafana.
    *   **Health Checks**: The `healthz` service periodically pings the main backend's `/healthz` endpoint. It is configured to notify a Telegram chat on any changes in the application's health status.
*   **Dependency Updates**: `dependabot.yml` and `renovate.json` are configured for automated dependency version updates across all relevant ecosystems (Cargo, npm, GitHub Actions, Docker). `renovate` includes custom managers for `rust-toolchain.toml`, `.npmrc`, and `cargo install` versions specified in Dockerfiles.

## 9. Security

Security is deeply integrated throughout Koso's design, from initial user authentication to data validation and external service integrations.

*   **Authentication**:
    *   **Google OAuth**: Users authenticate securely using their existing Google accounts. The backend meticulously verifies the integrity and authenticity of Google ID tokens using the `jsonwebtoken` library and Google's official public key certificates.
    *   **JWT (Bearer Tokens)**: Authenticated sessions are managed via JSON Web Tokens (JWTs). These tokens are passed in the `Authorization` header for all HTTP requests and, notably, within the `Sec-Websocket-Protocol` header for WebSocket connections, ensuring authenticated real-time communication.
*   **Authorization**:
    *   **Role-Based Access Control (RBAC)**:
        *   **Project Access**: The `project_permissions` table rigorously controls access, ensuring that users can only interact with projects for which they have been explicitly granted permission. The `verify_project_access` middleware consistently enforces this.
        *   **Premium Features**: The `verify_premium` middleware restricts access to certain advanced features (e.g., adding project members, listing all users) exclusively to premium subscribers.
    *   **Self-Access**: Certain sensitive endpoints, such as `GET /api/users/{email}`, are strictly restricted to only allow access by the authenticated user's own email.
*   **Secret Management**:
    *   **Dedicated Secrets Directory**: Sensitive keys and tokens (e.g., GitHub App private key, Stripe secret key, HMAC key for JWT signing) are stored in a dedicated `.secrets` directory outside the main codebase. They are accessed securely at runtime via `secrets.rs`, preventing their accidental commit to version control.
    *   **Environment Variables**: Non-sensitive configuration variables are managed exclusively through environment variables, following best practices for application configuration.
*   **Webhook Security**:
    *   **Signature Validation**: All incoming webhooks from external services (GitHub, Stripe, Discord) undergo rigorous validation. This involves using HMAC-SHA256 signatures with shared secrets (or Ed25519 for Discord) to ensure the authenticity of the payload and prevent spoofing. This is paramount for protecting against malicious event injection.
    *   **Timestamp Verification**: Webhooks are checked for staleness by verifying their timestamps against the current time, mitigating replay attacks.
    *   **Secret Tokens**: Telegram webhooks employ a shared secret token for validation, adding an extra layer of security.
*   **Input Validation**:
    *   **API Validation**: Backend API endpoints perform comprehensive validation on all incoming request bodies and query parameters (e.g., `validate_project_name` for length and content, `validate_redirect_url` for integrity).
*   **Data Integrity (CRDTs)**: The use of Yjs CRDTs intrinsically handles concurrent edits from multiple users without data loss or corruption, ensuring collaborative integrity and a consistent shared state.
*   **Dependency Security**: Automated dependency updates via Dependabot and Renovate are instrumental in promptly identifying and addressing known vulnerabilities in third-party libraries, reducing the attack surface.
*   **Vulnerability Reporting**: A clear `SECURITY.md` document outlines the policy and procedures for responsibly reporting vulnerabilities, encouraging community participation in maintaining security.

## 10. Future Work

Based on the current architecture and common application needs, several areas are ripe for future development to enhance Koso's capabilities and user experience:

*   **Advanced Access Control**: Implement more granular roles and permissions beyond basic project access (e.g., read-only users, admin roles within projects, fine-grained task permissions).
*   **Notifications Customization**: Allow users to configure more fine-grained notification preferences (e.g., notify only on specific status changes, per-task notification settings, digest emails).
*   **More Integrations**: Expand the plugin ecosystem to support other popular project management and communication tools (e.g., Jira, Asana, Google Workspace, Linear, Figma).
*   **Real-time Metrics & Dashboards**: Enhance monitoring capabilities with more detailed, real-time dashboards and automated alerts beyond basic health checks, possibly integrating with Grafana.
*   **Offline Support**: Improve the frontend's ability to operate fully offline with eventual consistency, leveraging IndexedDB more comprehensively for local data storage and synchronization when connectivity is restored.
*   **Performance Optimizations**: Investigate further optimizations for large projects (e.g., partial document loading for Yjs, more aggressive Yjs compaction strategies, lazy loading of UI components).
*   **Client-side Data Caching**: Implement more sophisticated client-side caching strategies to reduce redundant API calls and improve perceived responsiveness, especially for frequently accessed data.
*   **Internationalization (i18n)**: Support multiple languages for the user interface to cater to a global audience.
*   **Search Enhancements**: Implement advanced full-text search capabilities for tasks and projects, including filtering and sorting options.
*   **AI Agent Workflow Orchestration**: Develop more complex AI-driven workflows that interact with Koso tasks in an automated and intelligent manner, potentially enabling fully autonomous planning or task triage.

d01eebae-e9cb-42d6-a866-7c32f194b5ef.name: MVP Workflows: Engineers, Product Mangers, and Executives
d01eebae-e9cb-42d6-a866-7c32f194b5ef.desc:
# PRD

## Personas

### Engineer

Engineers should be able to organize their own work. Should automatically pull in tasks from various external sources including:

  - GitHub Issues [koso-956](https://koso.app/projects/CZVDD94wT5KrFwAv1hhejg?taskId=26903835-e7e5-4410-b605-bdb6ffc321cc)
  - GitHub PRs [koso-93](https://koso.app/projects/CZVDD94wT5KrFwAv1hhejg?taskId=bdeb9a13-f645-439b-9aa1-bd1ccd89c380)
  - TODOs in their codebase [koso-286](https://koso.app/projects/CZVDD94wT5KrFwAv1hhejg?taskId=3d4eb4c2-ac22-44b1-94b8-c6222495c750)

[koso-955](https://koso.app/projects/CZVDD94wT5KrFwAv1hhejg?taskId=8d95c0ff-fe7b-4340-a23c-9f9b80cfdf47)

Engineers should be encouraged to achieve zero inbox. Some techniques to encourage behavior include gamification with badges and / or streaks.

### Product Managers

[koso-954](https://koso.app/projects/CZVDD94wT5KrFwAv1hhejg?taskId=3a9d89de-31c4-4623-85a0-aa96825baf8b)

Product managers should be able to prioritize work.

### Executive

[koso-285](https://koso.app/projects/CZVDD94wT5KrFwAv1hhejg?taskId=095d004d-490e-4d34-b229-c63f39e26e99)

Executives (managers / directors) should have visibility into the progress of their project and the evolving complexity. The goal is to enable executives to identify potential problems in the project's execution and provide necessary resources or escalation to solve those problems.

[koso-648](https://koso.app/projects/CZVDD94wT5KrFwAv1hhejg?taskId=dae27b7f-8a3e-46f1-b26c-3397f616175a)

Executives should have a quick summary of the current progress of the project and whether or not we are green (all good) / yellow (at risk) / red (off track).

### Teams

Teams should have visibility into the current iteration. Engineers should be presented with additional work once they've achieved zero inbox.

## Workflows

### Sending PRs

[koso-957](https://koso.app/projects/CZVDD94wT5KrFwAv1hhejg?taskId=23bb1e72-127b-47e4-9822-59f5731df7b4)

One engineer should be able to send a PR to another engineer, and that engineer will see the PR in their Inbox. 

This workflow encourages engineers to pay attention to the tasks in their inbox.

### Blocking Tasks

[koso-925](https://koso.app/projects/CZVDD94wT5KrFwAv1hhejg?taskId=2dfa8971-6e25-491e-b598-23f4c7878e6a)

If an engineer is blocked on something getting done from another engineer or team, that engineer should be able to:

  - Block the task on a new task
  - Add a name / description to the task
  - Assign the task to another engineer

This workflow allows complex relationships in the project plan to be evolved.

### Tracking Project Progress

[koso-285](https://koso.app/projects/CZVDD94wT5KrFwAv1hhejg?taskId=095d004d-490e-4d34-b229-c63f39e26e99)

Managers and directors will want to understand where the critical path in the project exists. There should be a view that shows the critical path and enables them to help unblock issues by escalation or providing more resources.

### Deduping of Tasks

[koso-826](https://koso.app/projects/CZVDD94wT5KrFwAv1hhejg?taskId=7dfda6b1-576b-4aa5-bed3-dbd1081ce9ef)

When someone (engineer / manager / director) files a task, there should be an automated workflow that ensures tasks are not duplicated. Duplicates tasks should show up in the inbox of the user who is most likely to be able to make a decision.
